markdown:
<title
    level="1"
    right="Weapon 0"
    pfs="Standard"
>
[Tricky Pick](/Weapons.aspx?ID=481)
</title>

<traits>
<trait label="Uncommon" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=721" />
<trait label="Backstabber" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=544" />
<trait label="Fatal d10" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=597" />
<trait label="Kobold" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=759" />
<trait label="Modular (B, P, or S)" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=807" />
</traits>

<column gap="tiny">

**Source** [Player Core 2](/Sources.aspx?ID=227) pg. 275 <sup>1.1</sup>

<row gap="medium">
**Price** 10 gp

**Damage** 1d6 modular

**Bulk** 1
</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Hands** 1

</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Type** Melee

**Category** Advanced

**Group** [Pick](/WeaponGroups.aspx?ID=10)
</row>

</column>

---

This ingenious kobold pick conceals several hidden traps that the wielder can activate to trick and befuddle foes with a variety of damaging blades and bludgeoning surfaces.

<title level="2">Critical Specialization Effects</title>

**Source** [Core Rulebook](/Sources.aspx?ID=1) pg. 283 <sup>4.0</sup>

Certain feats, class features, weapon runes, and other effects can grant you additional benefits when you make a Strike with certain weapons and get a critical success. This is called a critical specialization effect. The exact effect depends on which weapon group your weapon belongs to, as listed below. You can always decide not to add the critical specialization effect of your weapon.

[Click here for the full rules on Critical Specialization Effects](/Rules.aspx?ID=235).

<document level="2" id="weapon-group-10" />
name: Tricky Pick
